newsitem.title: THAILAND: ITT sees Hilton bid as helpful.
newsitem.headline: ITT sees Hilton bid as helpful.

text.p: A $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid by Hilton Hotels Corp. for ITT Corp. has strengthened ITT, which hopes to get leaner and raise shareholder value to avoid a takeover, an ITT official said on Wednesday.
"In a sense it had a very positive impact," said Daniel Weadock, senior vice-president of ITT and chief executive of the company's wholly-owned hotel group, ITT Sheraton Corp.

"We had a long-term plan to be implemented over a 3-1/2- to four-year period. Long term became nine months, once Hilton announced the takeover plan," Weadock said in an interview during a visit to Thailand.
ITT has been selling properties and assets it has deemed to be "non-core" to focus on the hotels and gambling businesses in an effort to thwart the hostile bid launched by Hilton in January.
Among the higher-profile assets sold by ITT were its 50 percent stake in New York's Madison Square Garden and a portion of its stake in French telecommunications company Alcatel Alsthom.
Weadock said the company's goal is to increase ITT's share price and convince shareholders against a takeover by Hilton.
He said a realistic goal for the share price this year could be about $80.

ITT stock was at $59.875 on Wednesday, down 62.5 cents, and has risen from about $42 before Hilton launched the offer. The stock has consistently traded above Hilton's bid on views that Hilton could raise its bid.
Hilton launched a $55-per-share cash and stock bid for ITT in late January. ITT rejected the bid, calling it inadequate.
